title: North Carolina Wants to Ban Tesla... And Only Tesla

comments.text:
I live in N.C. and as I have come to hate this hayseed state this is a 
total outrage come on N.C. grow up >>>if you have not figured it out yet 
its 2015 ......duh
time to put your down your horse and buggy and stop your crying and realize 
its time to grow up...its stuff like this that is keeping our human race 
from advancing to the next stage of social maturity?
KEEP KICKING THEIR ASS Elon Musk!﻿
comments.author: ed owens

comments.text: It is an American made car, what happened to patriotism?﻿
comments.author: Akaki “akayoda” Yohada

comments.text:
Woooh it's times like these that I'm so proud of living in NC. Gotta love 
our conservative and outdated legislature...﻿
comments.author: Jackisaboss1208

comments.text:
If the government of North Carolina wants to shoot it's voters in the foot, 
who are we to stop them?﻿
comments.author: John Benton

comments.text:
I don't think you understand..."Long outlived any usefulness that they've 
had" is the unofficial motto of the Republican party...

Also, "unfair competition" is the classic holy sword used by the corporate 
powers that be to squash anything new or challenging.  I forget if it was 
Brazil or Colombia, but one of them wanted to roast and market their own 
coffee product, rather than simply ship the beans to the US to be 
processed.  somehow the the US was able to punish them for "unfair 
competition", and preserved Latin America for a little while longer as a 
place that only exports raw materials at bottom dollar.﻿
comments.author: Richie Lomas

comments.text:
My neighbour bought a Tesla. Cost her 120k but it is awesome and she saves

months though.﻿

comments.text:
I think service and custom work has a lot to do with why third party 
dealers are there. Also the automotive companies do not want to take on 
huge networks of dealerships, thence PEOPLE. Imagine the union and all the 
other bullsht that would ensue if GM took over all the dealerships. I think 
it can be done but there are too many lawyers still alive for it to ever 
happen amicably.

That said, I totally agree with the notion that car dealers suck a big 
hairy one.﻿

Ban tesla??  Texas and NC car dealers "associations" are the weirdest

comments.author: volvocare

comments.text:
+Derek Dicks..great comments.  Tesla would be a car many Canadians would

comments.author: volvocare

comments.text:
I live in Alberta, and it's actually quite conservative here (compared to 
other provinces that is). But our oil companies do take the time to respond 
to us. :)

And I haven't seen a direct example of clean tech being suppressed anywhere 
near they way the US is against Tesla.
Suncor, and Cenovus have at least put up some solar and wind farms. :P

I feel like that's not nearly enough, but with constant pressure they might 
just realize they will get left behind if they don't change.

And since they are driven by profits, they couldn't stand to see their 
stock hit zero, becoming a champion of clean/free energy is not in their 
best interests.
comments.author: Derek Dicks

comments.text:
Paused at 10 seconds because I'm flabbergasted by the stupidity. 

To say ANYTHING about "the free market in action" within the context of ANY 
government entity, much less one that is contemplating restrictive 
legislation, is to freely show the world that you are FUCKING CLUELESS 
about what a "free market" even means.  It pisses me off to no end how 
simple free market capitalism constantly gets slandered by people who don't 
know what the fuck they are talking about. 

Pay attention America . . . if the market is manipulated in any way by the 
gov't, it is NOT a free market, and you do not get to blame the market for 
whatever shitty fallout that occurs because of that manipulation.  In this 
case, the auto dealers association SHOULD just go home and shove their 
thumbs up their asses.  Want to ban your competition?  Tough shit.  It's a 
free market.  But hold on . . . if they can MANIPULATE the market through 
the power of the gov't, they can gain an advantage.  That is NOT a free 
market.  Repeat:  that is NOT a free market.  Repeat:  that is NOT free 
market.  That is GOVERNMENT MANIPULATION.

Until we can get the laughably uneducated masses to understand that 
distinction, our economy will always be under attack.﻿
comments.author: rmcdaniel423

comments.text:

You cant mess with evolution.﻿

comments.text:
I am in Raleigh - and my comment is: NC politics are as unfair and illegal 
as ever. We have the best politicians money can buy. Out dogs are taxed. 
ALL our food is taxed, our gas is among the highest taxed fuel in the 
country, our posessions are taxed every year ( cars, tools, pets, homes, 
clothes,etc.) .  Hybreds have a yearly sur-tax...cause the oil companies 
don't get a profit that is adequate to pay for our politicians homes, trips 
and cars.  Yup-I call North Carolina home (until they take it for lack of 
paying them rent for all the items that I have purchased).  Come on down!﻿

comments.text: North Carolina is the most backwards state of all. ﻿
comments.author: TimeHopeFaith

comments.text:
I'm rather amazed that nobody in this forum takes the auto makers to task 
for not making great electric cars themselves. Certainly the automobile 
dealers should. The auto makers could have prevented this problem 
themselves if they would have pulled their act together and made great 
electric cars to begin with.

 The problem for the auto dealers is they've got nothing in their inventory 
to compete with a Tesla. They're screwed and they know it. This is a 
desperate move on their part. That's sad!

 In anycase if a person wants an Electric car ,,, These franchise laws are 
not going to stop them and that's the lesson the auto makers and dealers 
are going to have to learn. Even if it's the hard way.﻿
comments.author: fernsemer

comments.text:
+Pynaegan I think I do understand at least a little. Both the oil and auto 
industry have allowed themselves for the sake of greed to allow themselves 
to get stupid. Surely they couldn't expect to hide how good an electric car 
can be forever. Could they? But apparently they thought they could and are 
still trying to.
 In anycase if it's only about making money ,,, then the oil companies have 
gotten stupid again ,,, as there's a tremendous need for high quality 
batteries for electric cars and so there's much money to be made in the 
battery business.
 In anycase we've seen the destructive consequences of so many gas guzzle 
cars on the roads. That coupled with the high cost of gas it should be 
obvious the old ways of thinking can't continue to work anymore.

When I look at what's going on in the auto industry I'm sometimes reminded 
of a movie from a few years back called 'Other Peoples Money'  Part of the 
movie is about a company that wouldn't modernize with the technology of the 
times. If you've never seen it ,,, it's worth watching at least once. 
Especially the passionate speeches toward the end of the movie. I can't 
help but think that if a companies leaders won't give up thinking that 
doesn't work anymore ,,, then maybe it is best to let that company die out. 
Although it is sad for the employees caught in the middle.
comments.author: fernsemer

comments.text:
I don't think you understand what the *real* problem here has been all this 
time. The Oil industry and the auto industry have always been in bed 
together.

 Let's say *you* were the oil industry and one day you came home and found 
auto industry in bed with your nerdy neighbor *electric* *car*. Now 
electric car has been around for years but you never considered him a 
threat cause he was weak and couldn't go the distance but now he can 
through the miracle of battery enhancement. And best of all for auto 
industry, she doesn't need any of your artificial lubricants anymore.

These guys in N. Carolina are complete wankers, pure and simple. All the 
buyer needs do is get on the 'net, order his Tesla and it gets delivered 
with number plates on, registered, everything done right over their heads. 
There is nothing the losers can do about it. It's like legislating for 
rain. Elon Musk would of went to bed and got no sleep from breaking out in 
giggles after hearing about this pathetic, pointless and unlawful act from 
a bunch of failed gangsters.

Teslas showrooms are not garages. You can go in to touchy feely the bits, 
say thank you, go home or get on your mobile phone there and then to buy 
one. The shop is Tesla staffed to offer advice exactly like an Apple store. 
No quotas. I like. Way to go ;)﻿

comments.author: Randy Weaver

comments.text:
+Randy Weaver Come on admit it. You are acting like a dickweed who really 
does need to own or even drive one of these to really know what you are 
talking about.

Kevin has one power brick reading low. Even for the extra £13K he has has 
shelled out for "peace of mind"; they will not help out because they say 
the 4.5% per annum degradation is "normal" in his >£113K car that now only 
returns 159 miles!
£13K could replace every cell! Not be used to fob him off at every turn.

Sure people have complete battery packs replaced in Model S's with burst 
cells wires. And drive units and motors, and steering units and a litany of 
other defects.

The model S I drove made my Leaf feel like a seriously expensive and 
comfortable car.
comments.author: m1aws

where very happy with every thing. So no need to hear some bull shit tweet.

comments.author: Randy Weaver

comments.text:
+Tom . The sound system is over Ubuntu Linux. They do not make the 
speakers, amps nor the wires.
The steering is off a land rover. And has issues. Many have broken their 
mounting lugs.
The drive trains are breaking on every car within 12K miles if raced. The 
one I drove sounding like sh*t when stressed. The sales guy joked they all 
sound the same. Being an engineer; the alarm bells rang. This is a quality 
issue if they are not the same.

It wasn't a nice car with rattles, drumming and odd noises where cars on a 
similar price range simply do not have. The Leaf is better!

Suggest you have a read here. It reflects perfectly what I knew.
http://evtv.me/2014/07/milling-mire/

All the best with Teslas future. I'm out.
comments.author: m1aws

comments.text:

soundsystem (which BMW rated as the best on the market btw) is Tesla-made, 
and once the gigafactory is built, not only will tesla make their own 
batteries, theyll be making everyone elses too

Coal fired power plants are not subject to the mass/volume constraints that 
cars are. Coupled with steam regeneration, they are about twice as 
efficient as your normal average IC car. Your argument is invalid.
comments.author: Alex Levenko

comments.text: Down with the dealerships! We the people and Tesla will prevail!
comments.author: im1greatman

comments.text:
Good analogy , electricity is king. Centrally located power plants are way 
more "green" then any form of mobile power plant will ever be, and now Mr. 
Musk has shown us how to do it. Power pack exchange quicker then I can have 
a pee-break, is absolutely brilliant. Simple but brilliant. Who will be the 
first "major" manufacture to fallow his lead, I believe they all will 
eventually or die.
comments.author: danny sulyma

comments.text:
Even with 100% coal, you're still doing better than the national fleet 
average. A centralized coal plant, even when considering transmission loss, 
is more efficient than an internal combustion engine. There's also the 
aspect of base load power plants (like coal plants) having cheap, excess 
capacity available during off-peak hours (the time when most cars are 
charged) with no net increase in pollution.

comments.text:
A coal fired power plant that gets profit from using smaller amounts of 
coal per unit energy is more efficient than a car's engine, which gains 
profit for gasoline refiners by being less efficient and needing more 
gasoline per unit energy. Stop being retarded.

comments.text:

the old guard,you`ve had your chance and now its some one elses. Good luck 
to the full Tesla team,you are doing a fantastic job. Sincerely JF ( UK )

comments.text:
This car could be the holy grail we've been looking for. It's the prefect 
town car for large cities like L.A. Atlanta, Chicago, and Dallas-Ft. Worth. 
Imagine driving back and forth to work for $5.00 to $10.00 a week depending 
on the length of your commute instead of the $45.00 to 65.00 your paying 
now. The savings would cover full coverage insurance, pay the property tax 
and buy a fresh set of tires once a year. And the people in the Middle East 
get NOTHING. Imagine that

comments.text:
Deadly acid? Is that what you're on? New York is testing new buses from 
China's BYD, capable of 150 mile range and 4-hr fast charge. There are also

Works, roughly same cost as new diesel. Much lower running costs or stuff 
to break - which won't make the unionized mechanics very happy.

comments.text:
Thanks for your response DIO, you saved me from having to work at exposing 
how much of an uneducated moron you are. And to think I was worried you 
might be capable of mounting an intelligent response. Oil is typically 
found at ~6000 feet (far away from surface water), and you say transferring 
it from this depth, adding extra polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, 
naphthalene heavy metals and others chemicals linked to mutagenesis and 
carcinogenesis, then returning it to our watersheds is harmless.
comments.author: Chuck O
